Pd/BN catalysts for highly efficient hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to succinic anhydride Jiandian Wang Investigation Writing – original draft Changyong Sun Conceptualization Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing ⁎ Wenjun Xia Investigation Zhou Cao Investigation Guangzhe Sheng Investigation Xiaowei Xie Conceptualization Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Key Laboratory of Clean Chemical Technology of Guangdong Regular Higher Education Institutions, School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China Key Laboratory of Clean Chemical Technology of Guangdong Regular Higher Education Institutions, School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China Key Laboratory of Clean Chemical Technology of Guangdong Regular Higher Education Institutions, School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A 0.33 wt% Pd/BN catalyst has been proved highly active for the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of maleic anhydride (MA) to succinic anhydride (SA) at room temperature and highly selective to SA within a wide temperature range, far beyond the Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MgO catalysts. An SA productivity of 6000 KgSA KgPd −1 h−1 and a high TOF value of 9.0 s−1 can be achieved at room temperature on the Pd/BN, and the high SA selectivity over 99.7% can be retained at the reaction temperature up to 150 ºC. Detailed structural characterizations and reactant-adsorption/desorption tests have demonstrated that the support effect on MA hydrogenation is related not only to the adsorption configurations of MA on Pd, which exhibits the indirect effect of the support via the electronic interaction with Pd, but also to the direct adsorption of MA on the support itself. In particular, for our catalysts with the low Pd loading, the difference of metal centers is largely masked by the adsorption of the support itself. For the Pd/BN, the predominant MA adsorption on Pd through a di-σ mode, the weak MA adsorption with a small amount on BN, and a high H-spillover ability are responsible for its high activity and selectivity. Moreover, it has been also revealed that the catalyst prereduction temperature can change the catalytic performance of the Pd/BN through an integrated effect including the removal of residual chlorine on Pd and the growth of Pd particles. Graphical Abstract A Pd/BN catalyst is highly active for the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of maleic anhydride at room temperature and highly selective to succinic anhydride within a wide temperature range. ga1 Keywords Boron nitride Pd/BN Selective hydrogenation Maleic anhydride Succinic anhydride 1 Introduction Succinic anhydride (SA) is widely employed in the industries of food, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, dyes, and biodegradable plastics; hence, catalytic hydrogenation of maleic anhydride (MA), as a direct, environmentally safe, and economical route to manufacture SA, has attracted much attention [1–8]. Depending on catalysts and reaction conditions, MA hydrogenation presents a complex reaction network, in which the exclusive hydrogenation of the olefinic double bond generates SA, and its further hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis can produce γ-butyrolactone (GBL) [9–14], 1,4-butanediol (BDO) [11], tetrahydrofuran (THF) [11,15], butyric acid (BA) [16], propionic acid (PA) [17], etc. To date, it is still a challenge to develop highly active catalysts under mild conditions and inhibit the deoxygenation, decarbonylation or ring-opening reaction at high temperatures for MA hydrogenation to SA. Supported Ni [18,19], Cu [20,21], and Pd [22,23] catalysts have been frequently used for MA hydrogenation, among which Pd shows relatively higher low-temperature activity as well as higher SA selectivity. It is reported that, in a batch system or in a fixed bed reactor, a 98% MA conversion with 99% SA selectivity could be achieved over a 1 wt% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst at 80–100 ºC [23]. Generally, the support also plays an important role in supported catalysts, where the metal–support interaction can tune the geometric and electronic properties of metal active centers. Besides, the support itself can directly affect the performance of supported catalysts by the adsorption and conversion of reactants or intermediates [24]. For instance, the effect of surface acidic and basic properties of the support on the hydrogenation performance of supported metal catalysts has been extensively reported, such as in the aromatic rings hydrogenation over the supported Ni catalysts [25] and in the partial hydrogenation of acetylene over the supported Pd catalysts [26]. In MA hydrogenation, both activity and selectivity patterns have often been explained on the basis of support acidity/basicity and metal–support interaction. Cai et al. discovered that the surface acidity of the support favors the conversion of MA on the supported Ni catalysts, but is unfavorable for the selectivity to SA, while the surface basicity plays the opposite role [27]. Previous reports also showed that the presence of acid sites, especially Lewis acid sites, favors the hydrogenolysis to generate GBL on supported Ni catalysts [28–30]. Thus, it is essential to choose suitable support for highly efficient hydrogenation of MA to SA. Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) has been used as catalyst supports [31,32] or a catalyst [33,34] in various catalytic reactions due to its large thermal conductivity, superior temperature stability, excellent acid-base resistance, and specific coordinatively unsaturated edge sites. In our previous work [35], it was found that a BN-supported Pt catalyst exhibits high performance for the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde because the support BN with an inert surface and few acid-base sites favors a simple adsorption mode of the reactant dependent only on the supported metal. In this paper, we show an investigation on the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of MA over the BN-supported Pd catalysts. A 0.33 wt% Pd/BN catalyst has been proved highly active for MA conversion at room temperature and highly selective to SA within a wide temperature range, far beyond the Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MgO catalysts. The role of different supports is explored by detailed structural characterizations and reactant-adsorption/desorption tests. The effect of catalyst prereduction temperature is also discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Pd/BN catalyst with a targeted Pd loading of 0.33 wt% was prepared by impregnating h-BN (~25 m2/g, Weixi, Changsha) with aqueous H2PdCl4 (Sino-Platinum, Kunming) solution. After stirring well, the impregnation mixture was dried by rotary evaporator at 50 ºC for 2 h and then further dried in an oven at 110 ºC for 8 h. Before carrying out catalytic tests or some characterizations, a prereduction treatment is required. Briefly, 120 mg of dried sample was loaded in a tube reactor, purged with a 20 mL/min of N2 for 10 min, then heated in a 20 mL/min of H2 to 400 ºC at a rate of 5 ºC /min, and held at 400 ºC for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature under the H2 flow, the sample was purged with N2 again. The reactor is equipped with two ball valves at both ends. After reduction, the two ball valves were closed and then the tube reactor was transferred into a glove box, where the reduced samples were ground, weighed, and packed into sealed bottles. For comparison, the Pd catalysts supported on MgO and Al2O3 were prepared by the same procedure as the Pd/BN catalyst. 2.2 Characterization The Pd content was measured by the atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) technique on a Shimadzu AA-6880. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded at − 196 ºC on a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ-2 instrument. Before the measurements, the samples were degassed at 250 ºC for 6 h. The specific surface area was calculated by the multipoint BET model, and the pore volume was obtained based on the adsorption at P/P0 ≈ 1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were taken on an FEI Tecnai G2F30 or G220 microscope using different modes with the maximum operating voltage of 200 kV. The specimen was prepared by ultrasonically dispersing the sample powder in ethanol, and drops of the suspension were deposited on a carbon-coated copper grid and dried in air. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected by a Thermo Fisher Escalab 250Xi using an Mg Kα X-ray (1253.6 eV) under ultrahigh vacuum condition (< 5 × 10−10 mbar). An additional pretreatment chamber allowed in situ reduction and transfer of the sample. The adventitious carbon 1s peak was calibrated at 284.8 eV to compensate for any charging effects. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics Auto Chem 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductive detector (TCD). For NH3-TPD, 100 mg of the prereduced catalyst was initially heated in an 80 mL/min of N2 to 300 ºC at a rate of 10 ºC/min and held at this temperature for 0.5 h. After cooling to 100 ºC under the N2 flow, a 5% NH3/N2 in a loop of 1 mL was periodically introduced until saturated adsorption. Then the sample was purged with N2 for 0.5 h to remove the weakly adsorbed NH3. Finally, the sample was heated in N2 from 100 to 800 ºC at a ramp of 10 ºC/min. For H2-TPR, the samples undergoing in situ prereduction and reoxidation were tested under a 5% H2/Ar atmosphere in a temperature range of − 20–800 ºC, while the interference of water and other products derived from the reduction process on the TCD signal of H2 consumption was eliminated by an isopropanol−liquid nitrogen trap. Before TPR, the dried samples were prereduced at 400 ºC for 2 h in a flow of hydrogen and then reoxidized at 400 ºC for 1 h in a flow of dry air. Compared with the dried precursor samples, on which large amount of ligand Cl- exist, the samples after a reduction and reoxidation treatment are less affected by ligand Cl-, which is helpful to simplify the analysis of Pd redox properties and better understand the support−metal interaction in the reaction system. Temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD), hydrogen (H2-TPD), and MA (MA-TPD) experiments were carried out on a Hiden Catlab equipped with a QGA mass spectrometer. Before all of the tests, 100 mg of the sample was in situ prereduced at 400 ºC for 2 h in a flow of hydrogen, purged with 40 mL/min of Ar at 410 ºC for 0.5 h, and then cooled to 40 ºC in the Ar flow. For CO2-TPD or H2-TPD, a 40 mL/min of 5% CO2/He or H2 was introduced at 40 ºC for 1 h to achieve adsorption equilibrium. After purged with Ar for 30 min, the sample was heated from 40 to 800 ºC at a ramp of 10 ºC/min under the Ar atmosphere. The desorbed species was monitored by recording the intensities of m/e = 20 and 44 or 2, and the amount of CO2 or H2 was calculated using Ar as an internal standard. For MA-TPD, a similar procedure was used, except that a 40 mL/min of Ar carrying saturated MA was introduced for 10 h to achieve adsorption equilibrium, and the MS signals of m/e = 20, 2, 18, 26, 28, 44, 54, 70, 72, and 98 were recorded during the heating process. Right after the MA-TPD test, a temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) was performed under a 40 mL/min of 20% O2/Ar in a temperature range of 40–700 ºC. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) data of CO and MA adsorbed on the catalysts were collected on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory and an MCT/A detector. A high-temperature cell connected to a gas flow control and vacuum system was used for an in situ reduction of the catalysts and the adsorption of CO and MA. The sample in the cell was reduced at the given temperature in a H2 flow, purged with 20 mL/min of Ar for 0.5 h at an elevated temperature, and then cooled to 25 ºC. The background spectrum was recorded. Subsequently, via a sampling valve with a loop of 100 μL, 5% CO/Ar was periodically pulsed into the cell. After 10 pulses, the physically adsorbed CO was purged with Ar for an extra 10 min. The CO adsorption spectra after each pulse and purge were collected using 16 scans referenced to the background spectrum. For MA, a 20 mL/min of N2 carrying saturated MA was continuously introduced into the cell for saturated adsorption followed by Ar purge and heating desorption. The spectra were recorded at a sampling interval of 5 min 2.3 Catalytic test The liquid-phase hydrogenation of MA was carried out in a 100 mL autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. The mass transfer limitation was eliminated when an agitation speed of 1440 rpm and catalyst pellet smaller than 200 mesh were used. In a typical reaction, 2.0 g of MA, 40.0 mL of 1,4-dioxane, 0.18 g of n-tetradecane, and 0.1 g of Pd catalysts were charged into the reactor, which was flushed with N2 for 5 times and further pressurized with H2 to the desired initial pressure. To avoid reoxidation of prereduced catalysts during catalyst loading, the partial solvent was injected into the catalyst bottle through the sealed septum using a syringe, which ensures that there is minimum contact with the environment. Then the reaction temperature was raised to the desired value and agitation was started. After different reaction periods, the liquid products were analyzed by an Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a HP Innowax capillary column, and the gas products were collected by a gas bag and analyzed by an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph equipped with a FID, a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), and a column system including TDX-01 and PlotAl2O3. The conversion of MA and the selectivity of products were calculated on the basis of the mass balance of carbon using n-tetradecane as an internal standard. In some kinetics measurements, a constant H2 pressure was kept. All of the experiments were conducted in triplicate for reproducibility of the data, and the results were within an error of ± 5%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 MA hydrogenation over the Pd/BN catalyst Fig. 1 shows the catalytic performance of the Pd catalysts over different supports and the Pd/BN catalyst under different reaction conditions in the liquid-phase MA hydrogenation. Compared with the Pd catalysts supported on two common supports, basic MgO and acidic Al2O3, the BN-supported Pd catalyst exhibited much better performance. As shown in Fig. 1a, a MA conversion of 100% was achieved over the Pd/BN catalyst at 25 ºC, while only 40.8% and 24.6% over the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3, respectively. This suggests that the Pd/BN has extraordinary low-temperature activity for MA hydrogenation, corresponding to an SA productivity of 6000 KgSA KgPd −1 h−1 at room temperature. Moreover, excessive hydrogenation over the Pd catalysts was completely suppressed at low temperatures, and thus the SA selectivity of 100% was obtained. Note, although no GBL, THF, BDO, BA, PA, butanol, and propanol could be detected in the liquid products, and no CO, CH4 and other light hydrocarbon could be detected in the gas products, there was usually a very small amount of succinic acid (selectivity < 0.3%) in the liquid products, indicating the presence or generation of water in the reaction system and the trace hydrolysis of SA. The water needed for succinic acid formation should come from the feed gas or the catalyst because no deoxygenation product formed. Considering that succinic acid is also the product via the exclusive hydrogenation of the olefinic double bond, the selectivity to succinic acid is not given separately, but counted in the SA selectivity. Fig. 2a displays the curves of ln(C0/C) versus reaction time under a constant H2 pressure at 25 ºC. The linear plots suggest that, over the three catalysts, the reaction follows pseudo first order kinetics with respect to MA. The rate constants over the Pd/BN, Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 were 1.56, 0.51 and 0.27 h−1, respectively, and the corresponding initial reaction rates were 0.316, 0.103 and 0.054 mol gcat. −1 h−1, respectively. Harsh reaction condition, such as high temperature or high hydrogen pressure, can enhance the conversion of MA, which helps to achieve high SA productivity. However, this can usually lead to excessive hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis, undesired side reactions as well as increasing separation complexity. Moreover, in view of the strong exothermic effect of hydrogenation and the difficulty of heat extraction in an industrial scale reactor, the local temperature of the catalyst is often higher than that expected. Therefore, it is pivotal for a MA hydrogenation catalyst to be highly selective to SA within a wide temperature range. Fig. 1c shows the results of MA hydrogenation at 150 ºC on the three catalysts. After a 20 min reaction, the Pd/BN exhibited a MA conversion of 100% with the SA selectivity of 99.7%, while the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 gave much lower SA selectivity in the case of incomplete MA conversion. Obviously, a high SA selectivity can be retained over the Pd/BN at high temperatures. PA and CO were the only by-products over the Pd/BN and Pd/Al2O3, indicating that the decarbonylation occurred at high temperatures. In addition to PA and CO, CH4 was also detected over the Pd/MgO. We speculate that CH4 was probably formed by the hydrogenation of CO from the decarbonylation, and the strong electron-donating characteristic of MgO promoted the methanation ability of Pd. A control experiment confirms that the Pd/MgO does convert CO to CH4 under the same conditions. Previous reports showed that, over a supported Co, Ni [4] or Pt [17] catalyst, the PA in MA hydrogenation is derived from the hydrogenolysis of intermediate SA or GBL. In another set of control experiments, SA was used as the initial reactant, and no PA was detected under the same conditions. This suggests that PA should be derived from the decarbonylation of MA over our Pd catalysts, and it seems that the decarbonylation and ring olefinic double bond hydrogenation occur simultaneously in those MA molecules that are converted to PA. Besides, the Pd/BN has high SA selectivity at 150 ºC, which is higher than the SA melting point of 118 ºC, implying that a more economical, solvent-free reaction mode is possible and worthy of further exploration. Fig. 1d-f show the effect of reaction time, initial H2 pressure, and catalyst reuse on the MA conversion and SA selectivity over the Pd/BN at 25 ºC. When the reaction conditions needed for the complete conversion of MA were far exceeded, such as a reaction time of 2 h (Fig. 1d) and an initial H2 pressure of 4 MPa (Fig. 1e), the SA selectivity remained unchanged, indicating high operation tolerance. When the Pd/BN catalyst was reused for four cycles by simple centrifugation separation without other treatment, the MA conversion and SA selectivity remained close to 100% (Fig. 1f), which demonstrates the excellent catalytic stability and recycling ability of the Pd/BN catalyst. Briefly, the above reaction evaluation has proved that the Pd/BN catalyst is highly active at room temperature, highly selective to SA within a wide temperature range, and quite stable, which is promising for the selective hydrogenation of MA to SA. 3.2 Role of the supports To obtain insights into the origin of the great difference in the catalytic performance of the Pd-based catalysts over different supports, the physicochemical properties of the three catalysts were characterized by means of various techniques and some are summarized in Table 1. The N2 adsorption−desorption measurements show that the Al2O3-supported Pd catalyst has the highest specific surface area and pore volume, which is obviously inherited from the support, and the Pd/BN and Pd/MgO exhibit much lower specific surface area and pore volume (Table 1). In combination with the reaction data in Fig. 1, it can be found that the catalytic performance is not related to the specific surface area or the pore volume on the Pd catalysts. Atomic absorption spectrometry tests show that the actual Pd content, in a range of 0.31–0.34 wt% for all of the three catalysts, is close to the targeted Pd loading of 0.33 wt%. The XRD patterns of the prereduced Pd catalysts over different supports are depicted in Fig. 2. For the Pd/BN, a series of peaks at 26.8, 41.7, 43.9, 50.3, 55.2, and 76.1º can be observed, which is indexed to the (002), (100), (101), (102), (004) and (110) diffractions of hexagonal boron nitride. In addition to the diffractions derived from the support BN, no diffraction attributed to Pd phase appears. The same case can also be observed on the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3. The absence of Pd diffraction over all catalysts is due to the low content of Pd, which can directly affect the possibility of detecting metallic Pd crystallites. Besides, low content of Pd causes a relatively high dispersion, forming large amount of small-sized crystallites beyond XRD detection limit, which also contributes to this. Fig. 3 shows the typical HAADF-STEM images of the Pd catalysts over different supports and the corresponding Pd particle size statistics. It should be noted that more than 20 TEM images of each catalyst were taken at random to ensure the representativeness of size statistics. The average Pd particles sizes over the Pd/BN, Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 are 3.3, 3.1 and 4.7 nm, respectively. It seems reasonable that the Pd/Al2O3 with the largest Pd particles (4.7 nm) displayed the lowest activity for MA hydrogenation because large particles expose less active centers. However, the Pd/MgO with smaller Pd particles (3.1 nm) displayed lower activity than the Pd/BN with larger Pd particles (3.3 nm), which cannot be explained by the size effect of Pd obviously. Thus, the difference in the Pd dispersion is not responsible for the great difference in the catalytic performance of the Pd catalysts. The different TOF values of MA hydrogenation on different catalysts based on the Pd surface atom confirm this. As shown in Table 1, the TOF values over the Pd/BN, Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 are 9.0, 2.6 and 2.0 s−1, respectively, suggesting that the Pd/BN has the highest intrinsic activity for MA hydrogenation. Fig. 4 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the Pd catalysts over different supports. A major H2 consumption peak at 30 ºC and a shoulder below 92 ºC could be observed on the Pd/BN, indicating a two stage reduction process. For the Pd/MgO, a major H2 consumption peak at 18 ºC, two shoulders below 155 ºC, and a bump at 300 ºC appear, and the negative peak at 55 ºC is due to the decomposition of β-PdHx species [36]. The Pd/Al2O3 displays a broad H2 consumption peak below 500 ºC with the apex at 84 ºC. Compared with the Pd/BN and Pd/MgO, Pd/Al2O3 shows higher reduction temperature of the major peak, implying the stronger interaction between the support and the Pd species. Previous report [37] discovered that strong interaction between support and metal is unfavorable for MA hydrogenation, so a diatomite-supported Ni catalyst without metal−support interaction shows higher activity than a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with strong interaction between Ni and Al2O3. It seems that this is also in part applicable to our Pd catalysts. However, for the non-reducible supports used here, the support−metal interaction is limited, the acid−base property is a more critical factor related to catalysis. Therefore, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were performed to examine the acidity and basicity of the Pd catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5, almost no NH3 and CO2 desorption on the Pd/BN could be observed, indicating that the Pd/BN has few acidic and basic surface sites. For the Pd/MgO, the absence of NH3 desorption and the presence of CO2 desorption suggest that the Pd/MgO has only basic surface sites, and the CO2 desorption at low temperatures (<150 ºC) and high temperatures (>450 ºC) corresponds to the surface sites with weak and strong basicity, respectively. For the Pd/Al2O3, a relatively large amount of NH3 desorption in a wide temperature range shows the abundant acidic surface sites with different strength. The CO2 desorption at low temperatures (<150 ºC) and medium temperatures (330–420 ºC) suggests that the Pd/Al2O3 also has the surface sites with weak and medium basicity. In combination with the results of MA hydrogenation, it seems that both acidic and basic surface sites on the Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MgO had an adverse effect on the MA conversion and SA selectivity, whereas the Pd/BN without acid-base sites exhibited outstanding activity and selectivity. It is well known that the acid-base property of supports can tune the geometric and electronic characteristic of metal active centers and in turn modify the catalytic performance. So, Pd 3d XPS were conducted to investigate the electronic effect of the supports. As shown in Fig. 6 and Table S1, after an in situ reduction, most of the Pd species are in the metallic state on all catalysts, and a few are Pd2+ derived from the interface between Pd particles and supports. The Pd/BN exhibits the standard binding energy of metallic Pd 3d5/2 at 335.3 eV, indicating no electronic interaction with the support BN. The binding energies of metallic Pd are 334.9 and 335.5 eV on the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3, respectively, which is lower or higher than the standard value by 0.4 or 0.2 eV, suggesting the charge transfer from MgO to Pd, or from Pd to Al2O3, and the resulting higher or lower electron density of Pd. This is consistent with the nature of the supports that the basic MgO is electron-donating, while the acidic Al2O3 is electron-withdrawing. The geometric and electronic characteristics of the Pd species supported on different supports were further explored by a diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy using CO as a probe molecule (CO-DRIFTS, Fig. 7). Over the three catalysts, two wide peaks at 2000–2100 and 1800–2000 cm−1 related to metallic Pd species could be observed, the former is assigned to a linear configuration that CO molecules are adsorbed onto single Pd sites, while the latter includes a bridge mode (1900–2000 cm−1) and a 3-fold hollow mode (1800–1900 cm−1) that CO molecules are adsorbed onto ensemble Pd [38,39]. Moreover, due to the CO adsorbed onto the oxide supports, the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 display remarkable carbonates IR vibration, which is absent on the Pd/BN. For the Pd/Al2O3, two kinds of linear CO peaks centered at 2074 and 2054 cm−1 could be distinguished, corresponding respectively to the CO bound to particle corner sites and the CO residing on edge sites [40,41], whereas the peak related to edge sites cannot be distinctly distinguished on the Pd/BN and Pd/MgO. Based on the peak deconvolution (Table S2), the ratio of edge sites/corner sites follows an order of Pd/Al2O3 > Pd/BN > Pd/MgO, implying the same order of Pd particle size on the catalysts because larger Pd particle has larger ratio of edge sites/corner sites, which is in accordance with the TEM statistics (Fig. 3 and Table 1). In addition to the effect of Pd size on CO adsorption, no effect derived from the supports can be directly observed or inferred in the CO-DRIFTS, although the supports changes the electron density of Pd, evidenced by the XPS results. DRIFTS was also used to examine the adsorption mode of the reactant MA over the Pd catalysts and the supports. Fig. 8 shows the spectra recorded after saturated MA adsorption and inert gas purging at room temperature, and the MA reference spectrum is given as well. The spectra for detailed adsorption and heating desorption process are shown in Fig. S1-S3. According to previous literature works [7,42,43], the characteristic bands are assigned and marked in the figure. For the support BN, the bands attributed to the sp2 C-H stretches, the conjugated CO stretches, the C-O stretch, the OC-O-CO deformation, the out-of-plane ring vibration, and the CC wag can be discriminated. The relatively strong out-of-plane ring vibration and CC wag suggest that there are few restrictions acting on the ring plane and CC, i.e., the MA molecule plane is not closely attached to the BN surface in parallel, and the bonded position is independent of the CC. The bands of the C-O stretch and OC-O-CO deformation are very weak, implying that the bonded position is mainly related to anhydride functional group. Taking into account of the saturation of bonding on the BN surface, we speculate that MA molecules should be bonded to the coordinatively unsaturated boundaries of BN layers through the double bond O or ring O atoms. In contrast, for the Pd/BN, the bands of the C-O stretch and OC-O-CO deformation become stronger, while those of the out-of-plane ring vibration and CC wag attenuate. This suggests that the MA adsorption on Pd is mainly related to the CC rather than the anhydride functional group. We speculate that the MA molecule should be bonded to the Pd surface through the CC via a di-σ adsorption mode, and thus these MA molecules adsorbed onto Pd surface do not contribute to the bands of the out-of-plane ring vibration and CC wag. The weak out-of-plane ring vibration and CC wag on the Pd/BN is derived from the partial MA bonded to the support BN. The appearance of sp3 C-H and nonconjugated CO confirms the di-σ adsorption mode, which breaks the olefinic π bonding and in turn causes the transformation from the sp2 C-H and conjugated CO to the sp3 C-H and nonconjugated CO. The sp2 C-H band can still be observed on the Pd/BN, which is also derived from the partial MA bonded to the support BN. Although the MA adsorption on Pd through a π mode will also display sp2 C-H vibration, this possibility is very small, because theoretical calculations [44] have demonstrated that a di-σ adsorption of MA on Pd(111) (–83 KJ/mol) is more energetically favorable than a π mode through CC (–34 KJ/mol). For the support MgO or Al2O3, the bands of the C-O stretch, the OC-O-CO deformation, the out-of-plane ring vibration, and the CC wag are very weak or cannot be observed, indicating that the stronger adsorption affects both the anhydride functional group and the CC. Because the ring olefinic double bond in MA is quite electron deficient, and the anhydride functional group is electronegative, the MA molecule exhibits very strong polarity. It seems that the MA molecule plane is closely bonded to the polar surface of the MgO or Al2O3 in parallel. Meanwhile, the bands of carboxyl CO and Mg-O/Al-O appear or strengthen, and the band of surface hydroxyl weakens (see Fig. S1). This is likely related to the formation of monomaleate induced by the surface hydroxyl. For the Pd/MgO or Pd/Al2O3, the bands of the sp3 C-H and nonconjugated CO emerge, suggesting that MA molecules are adsorbed on Pd through the CC via a di-σ adsorption mode as well. Compared with the Pd/BN, the Pd/MgO exhibits more intense C-O vibration, which cannot be seen at all on the Pd/Al2O3. A reasonable speculation is that the MgO-supported Pd species with higher electron density, as demonstrated by XPS (Fig. 6), has stronger repulsive effect on the electronegative anhydride functional group. As a result, there is a larger angle between the MA molecule plane and the Pd surface, which minimizes the effect on C-O vibration. Instead, the Al2O3-supported Pd species with lower electron density has weaker repulsive effect on the anhydride functional group; thus, there is a smaller angle between the MA molecule plane and the Pd surface that greatly suppresses the C-O vibration. For the Pd/BN, the medium electron density causes the medium angle between the MA molecule plane and the Pd surface. All the proposed configurations of MA adsorbed on different Pd catalysts are summarized in Scheme 1. According to the above proposed configurations, the anhydride functional group in MA molecule has the strongest interaction with the Pd species supported on the Al2O3, and thus it is easy to hydrogenolyze at high temperatures. This can well explain that the Pd/Al2O3 showed the worst SA selectivity at high temperatures (Fig. 1c). However, the comparison between the Pd/MgO and Pd/BN is puzzling. Although the Pd species supported on the MgO has weaker interaction with the anhydride functional group than that supported on the BN, the Pd/MgO showed lower SA selectivity at high temperatures than the Pd/BN. Therefore, there must be other factors affecting the SA selectivity besides the Pd species. To further investigate the adsorption behavior of MA over different catalysts and supports, MA-TPD and the subsequent TPO were conducted and are shown in Fig. 9. In the process of the MA-TPD, the signals of m/e = 26 (C2H2 +), 28 (CO+), 44 (CO2 +), and 54 (C3H2O+) could always be detected by an on-line MS over all of the supports and catalysts, and the fragments of 70 (C3H2O2 +) and 72 (C2O3 +) could be detected occasionally. No molecular ion signal of m/e = 98 (MA+) could be detected in all TPD profiles, indicating that MA had decomposed before desorption. Previous reports [43,45] also showed that the molecular desorption of MA can be observed only at much lower temperatures. Considering that the intensity ratios of the fragments detected for the various samples or at various temperatures are very different, the fragments should be mainly derived from different independent product molecules formed by the dissociation of MA adsorbed on the supports or catalysts. Based on this assumption, the main contribution for the m/e of 26, 28, 44, and 54 can be respectively assigned to acetylene, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and propynal, so their individual concentrations can be quantified after calibrating fragmentation patterns and MS sensitivity factors (detector response) using pure species diluted with Ar. The amount of residual carbonaceous species after TPD was determined by a subsequent TPO. Thus, the overall MA adsorption capacity can be calculated by converting the detected species to the MA based on carbon number and are listed in Table 2. Note, all the quantitative TPD results are based on the assumption that each detected fragment arises only from a single product, so they are approximate and given for easy discussion. Although MA had decomposed before desorption, the detected desorption behavior of the dissociated products can still reflect the interaction between the functional groups of MA and the support to a certain extent. As shown in Fig. 9, it can be found that only weakly bonded species exist on the support BN, evidenced by its low desorption temperature (<200 ºC); only strongly bonded species exist on the support MgO, which desorb at the temperature more than 300 ºC; both weakly and strongly bonded species exist on the support Al2O3, which desorb in a broad temperature range. In addition, the TPO results show the absence of residual carbonaceous species on the BN and the presence of residual carbonaceous species on the MgO or Al2O3. All these again confirm that the BN has weaker interaction with MA than the MgO or Al2O3. As aforementioned, different from the bonding to the Pd species, the MA molecule plane is closely bonded to the polar surface of the MgO or Al2O3 in parallel. So, the strong interaction between the anhydride functional group and the MgO or Al2O3 might also result in the hydrogenolysis at high temperatures and a lower SA selectivity, while the weak interaction between the MA and the BN ensures the higher SA selectivity of the Pd/BN. The total adsorption capacity of MA on the Al2O3 (189.6 μmol/g) is much higher than that on the BN (5.7 μmol/g) or MgO (8.0 μmol/g), which is related to the large specific surface area and the abundant surface acidic sites of the Al2O3. The percentage of the residual carbonaceous species (MATPO) in the total adsorbed MA (MAtotal) on the MgO is higher than that on the Al2O3, indicating the high ratio of strong adsorption sites on the MgO in spite of the small amount. When Pd was loaded, the total adsorption capacity of MA increases on all catalysts compared with that on the corresponding supports. As shown in Table 2, the percentage of MA adsorbed on Pd in the total adsorbed MA follows the order Pd/BN > Pd/MgO > Pd/Al2O3, which is well consistent with the activity order for MA hydrogenation (Fig. 1a-c). It can be found that, for the Pd/Al2O3, MA is mainly adsorbed on the support Al2O3 rather than on Pd, which is responsible for the very low activity of the Pd/Al2O3 in MA hydrogenation. Obviously, these MA molecules adsorbed on the support are more difficult to be hydrogenated than those adsorbed on Pd because hydrogen is dissociated only on Pd. For the Pd/BN, MA is mainly adsorbed on the Pd surface and can be hydrogenated readily, and the weakly adsorbed MA with a small amount on the support BN is also easy to migrate and hydrogenate. As a result, the Pd/BN shows an outstanding activity. Note, the exact amount of MA adsorbed on Pd cannot be obtained by calculating the difference between the Pd catalysts and the corresponding supports because the occupation of MA adsorption sites on the support surface by Pd loading needs to be considered. The actual amount of MA adsorbed on Pd should be higher than those listed in Table 2. Nevertheless, the difference in the percentage of MA adsorbed on Pd in the total adsorbed MA is large enough to reflect the real trend. Base on the above discussion, it can be found that, the performance of the Pd catalysts is related not only to the adsorption configurations of MA on Pd but also to the direct adsorption of MA on the support itself, and the effect of the latter is considerable. Considering the very low Pd loading of the catalysts, large amount of surface sites on the support should be preserved on the catalyst; hence, the considerable effect of support itself on the adsorption and migration of the reactant and the resulting catalytic performance are reasonable. In fact, previous theoretical calculations [2] have pointed out that the hydrogenation of MA to SA has a lower intrinsic activation barrier on the model metal surfaces where both MA and hydrogen are weakly adsorbed, and the adsorption strength of MA or hydrogen on the metal surface depends on the energy difference between the d-band center and the Fermi energy. However, it seems that, on our Pd catalysts with the very low Pd loading, although the support can affect the electron property of Pd, the difference of metal centers is largely masked by the adsorption of the support itself. Since the supports of our Pd catalysts can adsorb MA, a high H-spillover capability, i.e., effective dissociation of H2 and rapid diffusion of H atom on the support surface, is favorable for efficient hydrogenation of the MA adsorbed on the supports. To test the H-spillover capability, a mixture of WO3 and different Pd catalysts was fed with H2 at room temperature ( Fig. 10). The speed of WO3 color change can indicate the H-spillover capability of the catalyst because the spilled-over hydrogen migrates and readily reacts with the yellow WO3 to form dark blue HxWO3 [24]. The Pd/BN changes WO3 color most rapidly, as shown in Fig. 10, displaying a high H-spillover capability, which also contributes to its high activity. The Pd/MgO shows a medium H-spillover capability, while the Pd/Al2O3 shows a low one, which is consistent with the activity order as well. H2-TPD profiles ( Fig. 11) shows the adsorption of hydrogen on different surface sites of the catalysts. The low-temperature (LT), medium-temperature (MT), and high-temperature (HT) peaks can be assigned to the desorbed hydrogen from Pd, from the metal−support interface, and from the support, respectively [46,47]. Almost no HT peak exists on the Pd/BN, while the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 display significant HT peaks. This seems to be inconsistent with the results of WO3 reduction experiment (Fig. 10), since the Pd/BN with high H-spillover ability has almost no strongly adsorbed hydrogen on the support surface, whereas the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3 with relatively low H-spillover ability have large amount of strongly adsorbed hydrogen on the support surface. In fact, the spilled-over H amount on supports obtained by H2-TPD is a cumulative result after adsorption equilibrium including dissociation, interface migration, and surface diffusion. It does not reflect the diffusion velocity of spilled-over H, which is more important for catalysis and can be better reflected by WO3 reduction experiment. Moreover, the spilled-over H amount on supports obtained by H2-TPD (HT) is only based on the support surface sites as H-acceptors that can strongly adsorb H. Even if the diffusion of H is slow on supports (low H-spillover ability), the final accumulative amount of H on supports will still be large in the presence of sufficient support surface sites. This is different from the catalytic reaction, where the reactant can be continuously adsorbed on the support as H-acceptors along with the continuous desorption of the hydrogenation product. Almost no HT peak on the Pd/BN is only due to the surface property of BN that cannot provide surface sites to strongly adsorb H, suggesting that the adsorption of H on BN is weak. Possibly some weakly adsorbed H have desorbed at relative low temperatures, incorporating into LT or MT peak. According to the results of WO3 reduction experiment (Fig. 10) in which WO3 as H-acceptors, it is clear that the spilled-over H can diffuse rapidly on the surface of BN. Thus, the results of H2-TPD and WO3 reduction experiment are not contradictory because the weak adsorption of H on BN facilitates its rapid diffusion. In contrast, for the Pd/MgO and Pd/Al2O3, both supports can capture large amount of spilled-over H, which is derived from the accumulation in a long period of adsorption equilibrium, only reflecting that MgO and Al2O3 have more surface sites that can strongly adsorb H. The strong adsorption of H causes its low diffusibility on supports, which is also consistent with the low H-spillover ability observed by WO3 reduction experiment (Fig. 10). 3.3 Effect of catalyst prereduction temperature For supported metal catalysts, the calcination and/or reduction of metal precursor plays an important role in tuning the structural characteristics of the catalyst and in turn its activity, selectivity, and stability. We found that the calcination before reduction usually leads to a significant decrease in MA conversion on the Pd/BN, whereas the catalyst undergoing only reduction without calcination displays high MA conversion (Table S3). The hydrogenation performance of the Pd/BN has an intimate relationship with the catalyst prereduction temperature. As shown in Fig. 12, the MA conversion increases with the prereduction temperature in a range of 200–400 ºC, and the higher prereduction temperature (500 ºC) causes the decrease in MA conversion. It can be found that the Pd particles grow significantly at 500 ºC ( Fig. 13c), which is the main reason for its low activity. However, the size comparison of Pd particles on the catalysts prereduced at 200–400 ºC (Fig. 13a, b and Fig. 3a) shows no sharp difference. Therefore, the size effect of Pd is not the only factor affecting the catalytic performance of Pd/BN catalysts. It is well known that the residual chlorine can influence the performance of supported Pd catalysts using H2PdCl4 as metal precursors, although H2PdCl4 is easy to be reduced into metallic Pd. Fig. 14 shows the HCl discharge during the reduction process monitored by MS. A wide HCl peak with the apex at 380 ºC can be observed on the Pd/BN without prereduction. Because this peak of HCl discharge starts at 200 ºC, it is obvious that the prereduction at 200 ºC can hardly remove the residual chlorine. The low-temperature HCl discharge on the sample prereduced at 300 ºC decreases markedly compared with that on the sample without prereduction, and there is still high-temperature HCl desorption, suggesting that the prereduction at 300 ºC can only remove part of residual chlorine. When the prereduction temperature continues to rise, the residual chlorine can be almost completely removed, as confirmed by no obvious HCl discharge on the sample prereduced at 400 ºC. It seems that 400 ºC is an appropriate reduction temperature for effective removal of residual chlorine on the Pd/BN without the overgrowth of Pd particles. The CO-DRIFTS spectra of the Pd/BN catalysts prereduced at different temperatures further confirm this ( Fig. 15). Comparing the spectra of the catalysts reduced at 200 and 300 ºC, it can be found that the increase of reduction temperature results in the enhancement of all bands attributed to the adsorbed CO on Pd regardless its adsorption mode, indicating that a considerable amount of residual chlorine located on the different surface sites of Pd is removed at higher reduction temperatures. For the sample after reduction at 400 ºC, the linear and bridge-bonded CO bands continue to increase, suggesting the further removal of residual chlorine bonded to the corner, edge, and step sites of Pd particles [40]. For the sample after reduction at 500 ºC, all bands attributed to the adsorbed CO on Pd decrease due to the significant growing of Pd particles. Obviously, the effect of prereduction temperature on the hydrogenation performance of the Pd/BN originates from the removal of residual chlorine on Pd and the growth of Pd particles, by which the exposed Pd active sites can be increased or decreased. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a 0.33 wt% Pd/BN catalyst has been proved highly active for MA hydrogenation at room temperature and highly selective to SA within a wide temperature range, offering a promising alternative for the process that can be started up and operated without external heating, or for the more economical, solvent-free reaction mode in the industrial production. The support effect on MA hydrogenation has been demonstrated to be related not only to the adsorption configurations of MA on Pd, which exhibits the indirect effect of the support via the electronic interaction with Pd, but also to the direct adsorption of MA on the support itself. Both the capacity and the intensity of the MA adsorption on the support affect the performance of the catalyst. In particular, for our catalysts with the low Pd loading, the difference of metal centers is largely masked by the adsorption of the support itself. For the Pd/BN, the predominant MA adsorption on Pd through a di-σ mode, the weak MA adsorption with a small amount on BN, and a high H-spillover ability are responsible for its high activity and selectivity. Moreover, it has been also revealed that the catalyst prereduction temperature can simultaneously influence the removal of residual chlorine on Pd and the growth of Pd particles, and thus can change the catalytic performance of the Pd/BN. coredata.dc:description: A 0.33 wt% Pd/BN catalyst has been proved highly active for the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of maleic anhydride (MA) to succinic anhydride (SA) at room temperature and highly selective to SA within a wide temperature range, far beyond the Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MgO catalysts. An SA productivity of 6000 KgSA KgPd −1 h−1 and a high TOF value of 9.0 s−1 can be achieved at room temperature on the Pd/BN, and the high SA selectivity over 99.7% can be retained at the reaction temperature up to 150 ºC. Detailed structural characterizations and reactant-adsorption/desorption tests have demonstrated that the support effect on MA hydrogenation is related not only to the adsorption configurations of MA on Pd, which exhibits the indirect effect of the support via the electronic interaction with Pd, but also to the direct adsorption of MA on the support itself. In particular, for our catalysts with the low Pd loading, the difference of metal centers is largely masked by the adsorption of the support itself. For the Pd/BN, the predominant MA adsorption on Pd through a di-σ mode, the weak MA adsorption with a small amount on BN, and a high H-spillover ability are responsible for its high activity and selectivity. Moreover, it has been also revealed that the catalyst prereduction temperature can change the catalytic performance of the Pd/BN through an integrated effect including the removal of residual chlorine on Pd and the growth of Pd particles.
coredata.dc:title: Pd/BN catalysts for highly efficient hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to succinic anhydride
